section_title: Title and extent of operation of the Code
description: This section provides the title of the legislation, namely the Indian Penal Code, and states that it extends to the whole of India except the state of Jammu and Kashmir.
example_use_cases: The Code is applicable in all states and union territories of India for crimes committed within their jurisdiction.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a declaratory section defining the Code's applicability.

section_title: Punishment of offences committed within India
description: Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Code for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he is guilty within India.
example_use_cases: A foreign tourist committing theft in Delhi is subject to punishment under the IPC.
punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within India
description: Any person who, beyond India, commits an offence targeting a computer resource located in India, can be tried and punished under the IPC.
example_use_cases: A person located in a foreign country hacks into a server located in Mumbai.
punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences
description: The provisions of this Code apply to any offence committed by any citizen in any place without and beyond India, or by any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India.
example_use_cases: An Indian citizen commits murder in the United States; they can be tried under the IPC in India.
punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Certain laws not to be affected by this Code
description: This Code does not affect any special or local law, or any special jurisdiction or power conferred, or any special form of procedure prescribed, by any other law.
example_use_cases: A case under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act (NDPS Act) will be governed by that special law, not the general provisions of the IPC.
punishment: Not a penal section; it clarifies the application of special laws over the IPC.

section_title: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions
description: Every definition of an offence and every penal provision in this Code shall be understood subject to the exceptions contained in the Chapter entitled "General Exceptions".
example_use_cases: The definition of murder is subject to exceptions like private defence. If a killing is done in self-defence, it is not murder.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.

section_title: Sense of expression once explained
description: Every expression which is explained in any part of this Code is used in every part of this Code in conformity with the explanation.
example_use_cases: The word "voluntarily" defined in Section 39 must be interpreted with that meaning wherever it appears in the Code.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.

section_title: Gender
description: The pronoun "he" and its derivatives are used for any person, whether male or female.
example_use_cases: A woman can be charged with and convicted of an offence that uses the word "he", such as theft or murder.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.

section_title: Number
description: Unless the context indicates otherwise, words in the singular include the plural, and words in the plural include the singular.
example_use_cases: The phrase "the offender" in a section can apply to one or multiple offenders.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.

section_title: Man
description: """Woman""
example_use_cases: The word "man" denotes a male human being of any age, and the word "woman" denotes a female human being of any age.
punishment: A 17-year-old male can be referred to as a "man" for the purposes of the IPC.
column6: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Person
description: The word "person" includes any Company or Association or body of persons, whether incorporated or not.
example_use_cases: A company can be prosecuted for an offence requiring a specific intent, like cheating or fraud.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Public
description: The word "public" includes any class of the public or any community.
example_use_cases: An act done in a housing society common area can be considered an act done "in public".
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Servant of Government
description: The words "servant of Government" denote any officer or servant continued, appointed or employed in India by or under the authority of the Government.
example_use_cases: A clerk in a government office, a public school teacher, or a police constable is a servant of the Government.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Government
description: The word "Government" denotes the Central Government or the Government of a State.
example_use_cases: An offence against the Government of Maharashtra is an offence against a State Government.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: India
description: "India" means the territory of India excluding the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
example_use_cases: An offence committed in the state of Tamil Nadu is committed within "India" as per the IPC.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Judge
description: The word "Judge" denotes not only every person who is officially designated as a Judge but also every person who is empowered by law to give a definitive judgment in any legal proceeding.
example_use_cases: A Magistrate presiding over a trial, a Sessions Judge, or even an arbitrator empowered by law to give a final judgment is a Judge.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Court of Justice
description: The words "Court of Justice" denote a Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body.
example_use_cases: A Magistrate's court, a Sessions Court, the High Court, and the Supreme Court are Courts of Justice.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Public servant
description: The words "public servant" denote a person who falls under any of the descriptions provided in the section, including government officers, judges, court officers, military personnel, jury members, arbitrators, and any person holding an office to perform a public duty.
example_use_cases: A municipal corporator, a village sarpanch, a public university professor, and a government doctor are public servants.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Movable property
description: The words "movable property" are intended to include corporeal property of every description, except land and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth.
example_use_cases: Cash, jewellery, vehicles, livestock, timber once cut from a tree, and standing crops if agreed to be severed before sale are movable property.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Wrongful gain
description: """Wrongful loss""
example_use_cases: "Wrongful gain" is gain by unlawful means of property to which the person gaining is not legally entitled. "Wrongful loss" is the loss by unlawful means of property to which the person losing it is legally entitled.
punishment: A thief wrongfully gains stolen property; the owner wrongfully loses it.
column6: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Dishonestly
description: Whoever does anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person, is said to do that thing "dishonestly".
example_use_cases: A person intentionally submits a fake insurance claim to receive a payout (wrongful gain) and cause a loss to the insurance company.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Fraudulently
description: A person is said to do a thing fraudulently if he does that thing with intent to defraud but not otherwise.
example_use_cases: Creating a fake document to deceive someone into parting with their property is acting fraudulently.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Reason to believe
description: A person is said to have "reason to believe" a thing if he has sufficient cause to believe that thing but not otherwise.
example_use_cases: If a person buys a brand-new smartphone for a fraction of its price from a stranger on the street, he has reason to believe it might be stolen.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant
description: When property is in the possession of a person's wife, clerk, or servant, on account of that person, it is deemed to be in that person's possession.
example_use_cases: Money embezzled by a company clerk is considered to be in the possession of the company owner for the purpose of establishing liability.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Counterfeit
description: A person is said to "counterfeit" who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending to practice deception or knowing it to be likely that deception will be practiced.
example_use_cases: Printing fake currency notes that resemble real notes is counterfeiting.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Document
description: The word "document" denotes any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures, or marks with the intention of being used as evidence.
example_use_cases: A written contract, a printed receipt, an electronic record, a map, or even a lottery ticket are documents.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Electronic record
description: "Electronic record" has the meaning assigned to it in the Information Technology Act, 2000.
example_use_cases: An email, a digital database, a WhatsApp message, or a computer log file are electronic records.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Valuable security
description: A document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished, or released, is a "valuable security".
example_use_cases: A promissory note, a share certificate, a deed of sale for a house, or a will are valuable securities.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: A will
description: The words "a will" denote any testamentary document.
example_use_cases: A legal document that specifies how a person's property should be distributed after their death.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Words referring to acts include illegal omissions
description: In every part of this Code, except where a contrary intention appears from the context, words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal omissions.
example_use_cases: The word "act" in assault includes the illegal omission of a bus driver to apply brakes, causing injury.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.

section_title: Act
description: """Omission""
example_use_cases: The word "act" denotes a single act as well as a series of acts; the word "omission" denotes a single omission as well as a series of omissions.
punishment: A person who repeatedly harasses another over several days is committing a series of acts. A guard who repeatedly fails to perform his duty is a series of omissions.
column6: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention
description: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.
example_use_cases: Five people plan to beat a victim. Even if only one delivers the fatal blow, all five can be charged with murder under this section read with Section 302.
punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed, as if done individually.

section_title: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention
description: Whenever an act, which is criminal only by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention, is done by several persons, each person who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable.
example_use_cases: A group of people knowingly handle stolen goods; each one is liable for receiving stolen property because they all had the criminal intention.
punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission
description: Wherever the causing of a certain effect, or an attempt to cause that effect, by an act or by an omission, is an offence, it is to be understood that the causing of that effect partly by an act and partly by an omission is the same offence.
example_use_cases: A nurse (act) gives a wrong medicine and then (omission) fails to monitor the patient, leading to death. She is liable for causing death.
punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence
description: When an offence is committed by means of several acts, whoever intentionally co-operates in the commission of that offence by doing any one of those acts is liable.
example_use_cases: In a robbery, one person distracts the victim, another snatches the bag, and a third drives the getaway car. All co-operated and are liable for robbery.
punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.

section_title: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences
description: Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act, they may be guilty of different offences by means of that act.
example_use_cases: A and B plan to beat C. A has a stick, B has a gun. B shoots and kills C. A may be guilty of voluntarily causing hurt, while B is guilty of murder.
punishment: Punishment as per the different offences they are found guilty of.

section_title: Voluntarily
description: A person is said to cause an effect "voluntarily" when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which he knew were likely to cause it.
example_use_cases: A person throws a stone at a crowd, not intending to hit anyone but knowing it is likely. If someone is hit, he voluntarily caused hurt.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Offence
description: Except in the Chapters and sections mentioned, the word "offence" denotes a thing made punishable by this Code.
example_use_cases: Theft, defined in Section 378 and punishable under Section 379, is an offence.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Special law
description: A "special law" is a law applicable to a particular subject.
example_use_cases: The Arms Act, the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and the Prevention of Corruption Act are special laws.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Local law
description: A "local law" is a law applicable only to a particular part of India.
example_use_cases: A state government act or a municipal bye-law is a local law.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Illegal
description: """Legally bound to do""
example_use_cases: The word "illegal" is applicable to everything which is an offence or which is prohibited by law, or which furnishes ground for a civil action. A person is said to be "legally bound to do" anything if he is subject to a legal penalty if he fails to do it.
punishment: Trespassing is illegal. A witness is legally bound to tell the truth in court.
column6: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Injury
description: The word "injury" denotes any harm whatever illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.
example_use_cases: Physical assault causes injury to the body; defamation causes injury to reputation.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Life
description: The word "life" denotes the life of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.
example_use_cases: The offence of murder protects the "life" of a human being.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Death
description: The word "death" denotes the death of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.
example_use_cases: Causing the "death" of a human being is a key element in offences like culpable homicide.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Animal
description: The word "animal" denotes any living creature, other than a human being.
example_use_cases: A cow, a dog, a snake, or a bird is an animal.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Vessel
description: The word "vessel" denotes anything made for the conveyance by water of human beings or property.
example_use_cases: A ship, a boat, a yacht, or a ferry is a vessel.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Year
description: """Month""
example_use_cases: Wherever the word "year" or "month" is used, it is to be understood that the year or month is to be reckoned according to the British calendar.
punishment: A punishment of one year imprisonment means one year according to the Gregorian calendar.
column6: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Section
description: The word "section" denotes one of those portions of a Chapter of this Code which are distinguished by prefixed numeral figures.
example_use_cases: Referring to "Section 379" means the portion of the Code numbered 379.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Oath
description: The word "oath" includes a solemn affirmation substituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorized by law to be made before a public servant.
example_use_cases: An atheist witness can make a solemn affirmation instead of swearing on a holy book.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Good faith
description: Nothing is said to be done or believed in "good faith" which is done or believed without due care and attention.
example_use_cases: A journalist publishing a defamatory statement without verifying the facts cannot claim it was done in good faith.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Harbour
description: Except in Section 157, and in Section 130 in the case in which the harbour is given by the wife or husband of the person harboured, the word "harbour" includes supplying a person with shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition, or means of conveyance.
example_use_cases: Providing a hiding place, food, or money to a known fugitive from justice constitutes harbouring.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Punishments
description: The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Code are: Death; Imprisonment for life; Imprisonment, which is of two descriptions—rigorous (with hard labour) and simple; Forfeiture of property; Fine.
example_use_cases: A judge sentencing a convict for murder may choose between death and imprisonment for life.
punishment: Listing of permissible punishments under the IPC.

section_title: Commutation of sentence of death
description: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute a sentence of death for any other punishment provided by this Code.
example_use_cases: The President of India commutes a death sentence to life imprisonment.
punishment: Not a penal section; it deals with the power of commutation.

section_title: Commutation of sentence of imprisonment for life
description: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute a sentence of imprisonment for life for imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years.
example_use_cases: A state government commutes a life imprisonment term to rigorous imprisonment for ten years.
punishment: Not a penal section; it deals with the power of commutation.

section_title: Definition of “appropriate Government”
description: In Sections 54 and 55, the expression “appropriate Government” means the Central Government where the sentence is related to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, and the State Government in other cases.
example_use_cases: A death sentence for a crime under a central law like the NDPS Act would be commuted by the Central Government.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Fractions of terms of punishment
description: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years.
example_use_cases: This is used for calculating half of a life term for an attempt under Section 511.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a calculation rule.

section_title: Sentence may be (in certain cases of imprisonment) wholly or partly rigorous or simple
description: A court sentencing an offender to imprisonment for a term of up to one year can order that the imprisonment be wholly rigorous, wholly simple, or that part of it be rigorous and the rest simple.
example_use_cases: A magistrate sentences a person to six months imprisonment and orders that the first three months be rigorous and the remaining three be simple.
punishment: Specifies the court's discretion in ordering the type of imprisonment.

section_title: Amount of fine
description: Where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend, the amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive.
example_use_cases: For an offence where the punishment is stated as 'imprisonment and fine', the fine amount is at the court's discretion but must be reasonable.
punishment: Fine to be determined by the court, must not be excessive.

section_title: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine
description: When an offence is punishable with imprisonment and fine, the court may order that the offender shall undergo imprisonment for a certain term in default of payment of the fine. This imprisonment is in addition to the substantive imprisonment for the offence.
example_use_cases: A person is sentenced to one year imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 5000. The court also orders that if the fine is not paid, the person will undergo an additional two months imprisonment.
punishment: Imprisonment in default of fine payment, which is in addition to the main sentence.

section_title: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable
description: The term of imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall not exceed one-fourth of the maximum term of imprisonment fixed for the offence.
example_use_cases: If the maximum imprisonment for an offence is four years, the imprisonment in default of fine cannot exceed one year.
punishment: Imprisonment in default capped at one-fourth of the maximum substantive imprisonment term.

section_title: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine
description: The imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall be simple.
example_use_cases: A person unable to pay a fine will undergo simple imprisonment, not rigorous.
punishment: Simple imprisonment.

section_title: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only
description: If the offence is punishable with fine only, the imprisonment in default of payment of the fine shall be simple, and the term shall not exceed two months if the fine is not exceeding fifty rupees; four months if not exceeding one hundred rupees; and six months in any other case.
example_use_cases: A person convicted of a minor offence with a fine of Rs. 2000 who fails to pay may be sentenced to simple imprisonment for up to six months.
punishment: Simple imprisonment for a term based on the amount of the fine.

section_title: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine
description: The imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall terminate whenever the fine is either paid or levied by process of law.
example_use_cases: A person sentenced to one month in default of a fine is released immediately if the fine is paid at any time during that month.
punishment: Termination of imprisonment upon payment or recovery of the fine.

section_title: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine
description: If a part of the fine is paid, the imprisonment shall be reduced proportionally. The term shall be reduced by a fraction of the term equal to the fraction of the fine that has been paid.
example_use_cases: A fine of Rs. 1000 carries a default sentence of one month (30 days). If Rs. 500 is paid, the default imprisonment is reduced by half, to 15 days.
punishment: Proportional reduction of imprisonment term upon partial payment of fine.

section_title: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment—Death not to discharge property from liability
description: A fine can be levied at any time within six years after the passing of the sentence. The death of the offender does not discharge their property from liability to pay the fine.
example_use_cases: A convict avoids payment for five years; the court can still initiate recovery proceedings against their property. The fine can also be recovered from the convict's estate after their death.
punishment: Fine can be recovered within six years and is a charge on the offender's property, even after death.

section_title: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences
description: Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such offences, unless it is so expressly provided.
example_use_cases: A person commits theft in a building (Section 380). This offence includes the basic offence of theft (Section 379). They cannot be punished separately for both 379 and 380.
punishment: Punishment for one offence only, usually the one with the more severe penalty.

section_title: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which
description: In a case where it is doubtful which of several offences the facts proved will constitute, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided.
example_use_cases: A person is charged with theft and receiving stolen property. The evidence is unclear. The court convicts them for receiving stolen property if it carries a lower punishment.
punishment: Punishment for the offence with the least severe penalty.

section_title: Solitary confinement
description: A court can order that solitary confinement be inflicted as part of the imprisonment in certain cases. The total period of solitary confinement shall not exceed three months in any case. It must not exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals of at least fourteen days.
example_use_cases: A convict sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for a grave crime like murder may be ordered to undergo periods of solitary confinement.
punishment: Solitary confinement, subject to strict limits on duration and frequency.

section_title: Limit of solitary confinement
description: In executing a sentence of solitary confinement, such confinement shall in no case exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals of not less than fourteen days between each period of solitary confinement.
example_use_cases: A convict cannot be kept in solitary confinement for 30 days continuously; it must be broken up into periods of no more than 14 days each.
punishment: As per the limits described in Section 73.

section_title: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction
description: Whoever, having been convicted of an offence under Chapter XII (Offences against property) or Chapter XVII (Offences against property), is again convicted of any offence under either of those chapters, shall be subject to enhanced punishment.
example_use_cases: A person previously convicted of theft is convicted of theft again. The court can impose a longer term of imprisonment for the second offence.
punishment: Imprisonment for either description for a term which may extend to double the maximum term provided for the offence.

section_title: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law believes himself to be, bound by law to do it.
example_use_cases: A policeman, acting under a valid court warrant, arrests a person. This is not an offence of wrongful confinement.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act of Judge when acting judicially
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law.
example_use_cases: A Judge orders the imprisonment of a convict. This is not an offence of wrongful confinement.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court
description: Nothing which is done in pursuance of, or which is warranted by the judgment or order of, a Court of Justice is an offence, provided the person doing the act in good faith believes the Court had jurisdiction.
example_use_cases: A bailiff, acting on a court order, attaches the property of a judgment debtor. This is not theft.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by any person who is justified by law, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be justified by law, in doing it.
example_use_cases: A person sees someone being attacked. Mistaking the attacker for the victim, he uses force against the actual victim. This is not an offence due to a mistake of fact.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Accident in doing a lawful act
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by accident or misfortune, and without any criminal intention or knowledge, in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.
example_use_cases: A person chopping wood lawfully and with care accidentally lets the axe slip, killing a bystander. This is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm
description: Nothing is an offence merely by reason of its being done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause harm, if it be done without any criminal intention to cause harm, and in good faith for the purpose of preventing or avoiding other harm to person or property.
example_use_cases: To stop a fire from spreading, a person pulls down houses. This is not mischief, as it was done to prevent a greater harm.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act of a child under seven years of age
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.
example_use_cases: A six-year-old child picks up and takes away a toy from a shop. This is not theft.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing absolute immunity.

section_title: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion.
example_use_cases: A nine-year-old child of underdeveloped intellect sets fire to a house, not understanding the consequences. This is not arson.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity if maturity is lacking.

section_title: Act of a person of unsound mind
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
example_use_cases: A person in a manic episode, believing they are destroying evil spirits, breaks valuable items. This may not be mischief.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.
example_use_cases: A person is forcibly administered an intoxicating drug and, while in that state, commits assault. This is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
description: In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the intoxication was caused without his knowledge or against his will.
example_use_cases: A person voluntarily gets drunk and, while intoxicated, commits an assault. His voluntary intoxication is not a defence, and he can be held liable as if he were sober.
punishment: Liable for the offence, as voluntary intoxication is not a defence for forming intent.

section_title: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent
description: Nothing is an offence which is not intended to cause death or grievous hurt, and which is done by the consent of the person above eighteen years of age who understands the risk involved.
example_use_cases: A person consents to a surgical operation by a doctor. The operation is not an assault. Participating in a rough game like rugby where hurt is likely is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
description: Nothing which is not intended to cause death is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to the person consenting, if it is done in good faith for that person's benefit.
example_use_cases: A surgeon, with consent, performs a risky but necessary operation that results in harm. This is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian
description: Nothing which is done in good faith for the benefit of a person under twelve years of age or of unsound mind, by or by consent of the guardian, is an offence by reason of any harm it may cause.
example_use_cases: A guardian of a minor consents to a necessary medical procedure for the child. A parent physically chastising a child for correction is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
description: A consent is not a valid consent within the meaning of Sections 87, 88 and 89 if it is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact, or by an insane or intoxicated person, or by a child unless the contrary appears from the context.
example_use_cases: A person consents to sexual intercourse under a threat of violence. This consent is invalid, making it rape. A patient consents to an operation believing it is for a different purpose.
punishment: Consent is vitiated and cannot be used as a defence.

section_title: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
description: The exceptions in Sections 87, 88 and 89 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause.
example_use_cases: Causing a miscarriage is an offence under Section 312, even if the woman consents. Consent is no defence.
punishment: The act remains an offence despite consent.

section_title: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
description: Nothing is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to a person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, even without that person's consent, if circumstances exist that make it impossible to obtain consent and the doer believes the consent would have been given.
example_use_cases: A doctor performs an emergency life-saving operation on an unconscious patient after an accident. This is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Communication made in good faith
description: No communication made in good faith is an offence by reason of any harm to the person to whom it is made, if it is made for the benefit of that person.
example_use_cases: A doctor truthfully tells a patient they have a serious illness. This is not defamation or causing emotional distress.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act to which a person is compelled by threats
description: Except for murder and offences against the state punishable with death, nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is compelled to do it by threats, which, at the time of doing it, reasonably cause the apprehension that instant death to that person will otherwise be the consequence.
example_use_cases: A person is threatened with instant death unless they assist in a robbery. Their participation in the robbery is not an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Act causing slight harm
description: Nothing is an offence which causes, or intends to cause, harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of it.
example_use_cases: A person pushes another slightly in a crowded bus. This is not assault.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Things done in private defence
description: Nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence.
example_use_cases: A person has the right to defend their own body and property against an offence.
punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.

section_title: Right of private defence of the body and of property
description: Every person has a right, subject to the restrictions in Section 99, to defend their own body and the body of any other person against any offence affecting the human body. They also have the same right to defend their own property or the property of any other person against certain offences like theft, robbery, mischief, or criminal trespass.
example_use_cases: A person can use force to prevent a thief from stealing their car. A person can defend a friend who is being attacked.
punishment: The right to use necessary force, extending even to causing death in certain grave situations.

section_title: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.
description: When an act which would otherwise be a certain offence is not that offence due to youth, want of maturity of understanding, unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or misconception, the right of private defence against that act is the same as it would be if the act were that offence.
example_use_cases: A person attacked by a child or a lunatic can still exercise the right of private defence to the same extent as if the attacker were a sane adult.
punishment: The right to private defence exists even against acts of exempted persons.

section_title: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
description: The right of private defence does not extend to causing more harm than is necessary for defence. There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or grievous hurt, if done by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of their office. There is no right against an act done under the direction of a public servant.
example_use_cases: A person cannot shoot a pickpocket. A person cannot resist a lawful arrest by a police officer.
punishment: No right to defend exists in these scenarios.

section_title: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
description: The right of private defence of the body extends to voluntarily causing death if the offence which occasions the exercise of the right is of any of the following types: assault reasonably causing apprehension of death; assault reasonably causing apprehension of grievous hurt; assault with intention of committing rape; assault with intention of gratifying unnatural lust; assault with intention of kidnapping or abducting; assault with intention of wrongfully confining a person.
example_use_cases: A woman can kill a man attempting to rape her. A person can kill an attacker who is trying to kidnap their child.
punishment: The right extends to causing the death of the assailant.

section_title: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death
description: If the offence is not of any of the types enumerated in Section 100, the right of private defence of the body extends to causing any harm other than death.
example_use_cases: Defending against an assault that only causes or threatens to cause simple hurt.
punishment: The right extends to causing any harm short of death.

section_title: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of the body
description: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence, and it continues as long as such apprehension of danger to the body continues.
example_use_cases: The right starts not when the blow is struck, but when the threat is perceived. It ends when the attacker retreats or is disabled.
punishment: The right is available for the duration of the threat.

section_title: When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death
description: The right of private defence of property extends to voluntarily causing death when the offence which occasions the exercise of the right is of any of the following descriptions: robbery; house-breaking by night; mischief by fire on any building, tent, or vessel used as a human dwelling; theft, mischief, or house-trespass which reasonably causes apprehension of death or grievous hurt.
example_use_cases: A homeowner can kill a robber breaking into their house at night. A person can kill someone setting fire to their house.
punishment: The right extends to causing the death of the wrongdoer.

section_title: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death
description: If the offence is not of any of the types enumerated in Section 103, the right of private defence of property extends to causing any harm other than death.
example_use_cases: Defending property against simple theft or mischief during the day.
punishment: The right extends to causing any harm short of death.

section_title: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of property
description: The right of private defence of property commences when a reasonable apprehension of danger to the property begins. It continues against theft as long as the offender continues in the commission of theft or until the property is recovered. It continues against robbery during the continuance of the robbery. It continues against criminal trespass or mischief as long as the offender continues in the commission of such trespass or mischief.
example_use_cases: The right to defend property against a thief continues until the stolen property is recovered or the thief escapes.
punishment: The right is available for the duration of the criminal act against property.

section_title: Right of private defence against deadly assault when there is risk of harm to innocent person
description: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes apprehension of death, the defender is so situated that they cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, their right extends to the running of that risk.
example_use_cases: A person attacked in a crowded market can return fire even if there is a risk of hitting a bystander, provided the private defence right exists.
punishment: The right extends to taking the risk of harming an innocent person.

section_title: Abetment of a thing
description: A person abets the doing of a thing if they instigate any person to do that thing, engage with one or more other persons in a conspiracy for the doing of that thing, or intentionally aid the doing of that thing.
example_use_cases: Persuading someone to commit a crime, conspiring to commit a crime, or providing tools to commit a crime.
punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted, as per Section 109 onwards.

section_title: Abettor
description: An abettor is a person who abets an offence or who abets either the commission of an offence or the commission of an act which would be an offence if committed by a person capable of committing an offence.
example_use_cases: A person who aids a minor in committing theft is an abettor, even though the minor may not be punishable.
punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted.

section_title: Abetment in India of offences outside India
description: A person abets an offence outside India which would be punishable in India if committed in India. They can be tried in India for abetment.
example_use_cases: A person in Mumbai instigates someone in Nepal to commit murder in Nepal. They can be tried in India for abetting murder.
punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted.

section_title: Punishment of abetment if the act abetted is committed in consequence and where no express provision is made for its punishment
description: Whoever abets any offence shall, if the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence.
example_use_cases: A person instigates another to commit murder, and the murder is committed. The instigator is punished as a murderer.
punishment: Punishment for the offence committed.

section_title: Punishment of abetment if person abetted does act with different intention from that of abettor
description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence shall be punished with the punishment provided for the offence, even if the person abetted acts with a different intention or knowledge from that of the abettor.
example_use_cases: A abets B to burn Z's house. B, while doing so, also commits theft. A is guilty of abetting burning (mischief by fire), not theft.
punishment: Punishment for the offence which was abetted.

section_title: Liability of abettor when one act abetted and different act done
description: When an act is abetted and a different act is done, the abettor is liable for the act done in the same manner as if they had abetted that act, provided the act done was a probable consequence of the abetment and was committed under the influence of the instigation.
example_use_cases: A instigates a child to put poison in B's food. The child, by mistake, puts the poison in C's food. A is liable for the murder of C.
punishment: Punishment for the offence actually committed, if it was a probable consequence of the abetment.

section_title: Abettor when liable to cumulative punishment for act abetted and for act done
description: If the act for which the abettor is liable under Section 111 is committed in addition to the act abetted, and constitutes a distinct offence, the abettor is liable for punishment for each of the offences.
example_use_cases: A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. B does so, and also wrongfully confines Z. A is liable for abetting grievous hurt and also for the wrongful confinement if it was a probable consequence.
punishment: Cumulative punishment for both the abetted offence and the offence committed as a consequence.

section_title: Liability of abettor for an effect caused by the act abetted different from that intended by the abettor
description: When an act is abetted with the intention of causing a particular effect, and an act for which the abettor is liable results in a different effect, the abettor is liable for the effect caused in the same manner as if they had abetted the act with the intention of causing that effect.
example_use_cases: A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. B causes such hurt, and Z dies. A is liable for abetting culpable homicide.
punishment: Punishment for the offence which was the actual result of the abetted act.

section_title: Abettor present when offence is committed
description: Whenever any person who is an abettor in the commission of an offence is present when the offence is committed, they shall be deemed to have committed the offence itself.
example_use_cases: A instigates B to murder Z. A is present and assists when B murders Z. A is not just an abettor but is treated as having committed the murder himself.
punishment: Punishment for the offence committed, not just for abetment.

section_title: Abetment of offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life—if offence not committed
description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life shall, if that offence is not committed, be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, the abettor is punished as per Section 109.
example_use_cases: A instigates B to murder Z. The murder is not committed. A can be imprisoned for up to seven years.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Abetment of offence punishable with imprisonment—if offence not committed
description: Whoever abets an offence punishable with imprisonment shall, if that offence is not committed, be punished with imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence, or with fine, or both. If the abettor is a public servant and the offence is related to their duty, the imprisonment can extend to one-half of the maximum term.
example_use_cases: A, a public servant, abets B to commit theft. The theft does not occur. A can be punished with imprisonment up to half of the maximum term for theft (which is 3 years, so up to 1.5 years).
punishment: Imprisonment up to one-fourth (or one-half for public servants) of the maximum term for the offence, or fine, or both.

section_title: Abetting commission of offence by the public or by more than ten persons
description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence by the public generally or by any number or class of persons exceeding ten, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or both.
example_use_cases: Making a public speech instigating a large mob to burn down a particular community's houses.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life
description: Whoever intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that they will facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, voluntarily conceals the existence of a design to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If the offence is committed, the punishment is up to seven years.
example_use_cases: A knows that B is planning to murder Z and hides this information from the authorities to help B.
punishment: If offence not committed: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If offence committed: Imprisonment up to seven years.

section_title: Public servant concealing design to commit offence which it is their duty to prevent
description: A public servant who intends to facilitate or knows it will facilitate the commission of an offence which they are duty-bound to prevent, and conceals the design of that offence, shall be punished. If the offence is punishable with death/imprisonment for life, imprisonment up to ten years. For any other offence, imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
example_use_cases: A police officer knows a robbery is being planned but does nothing to prevent it and conceals the information.
punishment: If offence is serious: Imprisonment up to ten years. For other offences: Imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
description: Whoever, intending to facilitate or knowing it will facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment, voluntarily conceals the existence of a design to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence, or with fine, or both. If the offence is committed, imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term.
example_use_cases: A knows B plans to commit simple hurt and conceals it. The maximum for simple hurt is one year, so A can be imprisoned for up to three months.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for the offence, or fine, or both.

section_title: Definition of criminal conspiracy
description: When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done, an illegal act, or an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy.
example_use_cases: A and B agree to poison Z. This is a criminal conspiracy to commit murder.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 120B.

section_title: Punishment of criminal conspiracy
description: Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for two years or more shall be punished in the same manner as if they had abetted such offence. A party to a criminal conspiracy to commit any other offence shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
example_use_cases: Conspiring to commit murder is punishable as abetment of murder. Conspiring to commit a minor theft is punishable with up to six months imprisonment.
punishment: For serious offences: Punishment for abetment of that offence. For other offences: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Waging, or attempting to wage war, or abetting waging of war, against the Government of India
description: Whoever wages war against the Government of India, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Leading an armed insurrection against the Indian state.
punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine.

section_title: Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by Section 121
description: Whoever within or without India conspires to commit any of the offences punishable by Section 121, or to deprive the Government of India of its sovereignty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
example_use_cases: A group of people in a foreign country plan an armed attack on Indian soil to overthrow the government.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war against the Government of India
description: Whoever collects men, arms, or ammunition or otherwise prepares to wage war with the intention of waging war against the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
example_use_cases: Stockpiling weapons and recruiting people for an armed rebellion.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Concealing with intent to facilitate design to wage war
description: Whoever by any act, or by any illegal omission, conceals the existence of a design to wage war, intending to facilitate the waging of war, shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
example_use_cases: Knowing about a plot to wage war and hiding it from the authorities to help the plotters.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Assaulting President, Governor, etc., with intent to compel or restrain the exercise of any lawful power
description: Whoever assaults the President of India, or the Governor of any State, with the intent to compel or restrain them from exercising any lawful power, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
example_use_cases: Assaulting the President to force them to resign.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Sedition
description: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representation, or otherwise, brings or attempts to bring into hatred or contempt, or excites or attempts to excite disaffection towards the Government established by law in India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life (to which fine may be added), or imprisonment up to three years (to which fine may be added), or fine.
example_use_cases: Making speeches or publishing articles that incite violence or public disorder against the government.
punishment: Imprisonment for life (with possible fine), or imprisonment up to three years (with possible fine), or fine.

section_title: Waging war against any Asiatic power in alliance with the Government of India
description: Whoever wages war against the Government of any Asiatic power in alliance or at peace with the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, to which fine may be added, or imprisonment up to seven years, to which fine may be added, or fine.
example_use_cases: An Indian citizen joining a rebel army to fight against a friendly neighbouring country's government.
punishment: Imprisonment for life (with possible fine), or imprisonment up to seven years (with possible fine), or fine.

section_title: Committing depredation on territories of power at peace with the Government of India
description: Whoever commits depredation, or prepares to commit depredation, on the territories of any power in alliance or at peace with the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of property used in the depredation.
example_use_cases: A private militia from India raids a village across the border in a friendly country.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of property.

section_title: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 and 126
description: Whoever receives any property knowing it to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of the property.
example_use_cases: Buying looted goods that were taken during a raid on a friendly country.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of the property.

section_title: Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of state or war to escape
description: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any state prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
example_use_cases: A jailor deliberately lets a captured enemy combatant escape.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of state or war to escape
description: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any state prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape, shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to three years and fine.
example_use_cases: A guard falls asleep on duty, allowing a high-security prisoner to escape.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Aiding escape of, rescuing, or harbouring such prisoner
description: Whoever knowingly aids or assists any state prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue such prisoner, or harbours or conceals such prisoner who has escaped, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
example_use_cases: Providing a getaway car to a prisoner of war who has broken out of jail.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce a soldier, sailor or airman from his duty
description: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, or attempts to seduce any such person from his allegiance or duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
example_use_cases: Trying to persuade an army jawan to desert his post during a conflict.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny is committed in consequence thereof
description: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny shall, if mutiny is committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
example_use_cases: Instigating a group of soldiers to mutiny, which they then do.
punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Abetment of assault by soldier, sailor or airman on his superior officer, when in execution of his office
description: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman on his superior officer in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years and fine.
example_use_cases: Encouraging a soldier to hit his commanding officer who is giving a lawful order.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Abetment of such assault, if the assault is committed
description: Whoever abets an assault described in Section 133 shall, if the assault is committed, be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
example_use_cases: The abetment described in Section 133 actually results in the assault taking place.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Abetment of desertion of soldier, sailor or airman
description: Whoever abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
example_use_cases: Helping a soldier plan his unauthorized departure from the army.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Harbouring deserter
description: Whoever, knowing that an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman has deserted, harbours him, shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
example_use_cases: Giving shelter and hiding a deserter from the army.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Deserter concealed on board merchant vessel through negligence of master
description: The master or person in charge of a merchant vessel negligently suffers a deserter from the Army, Navy, or Air Force to be concealed on board, shall be punished with fine up to five hundred rupees.
example_use_cases: A ship captain fails to check his crew properly and unknowingly hires a deserter.
punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.

section_title: Abetment of act of insubordination by soldier, sailor or airman
description: Whoever abets an act of insubordination by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
example_use_cases: Encouraging a soldier to willfully disobey a lawful command from a superior.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Persons subject to certain Acts
description: No person subject to the Army Act, the Navy Act, or the Air Force Act is subject to punishment under this Code for any offence defined in this Chapter (Chapter VII).
example_use_cases: A soldier committing mutiny is tried under the Army Act, not under the IPC sections for mutiny.
punishment: Not a penal section; it specifies the jurisdiction of military law.

section_title: Wearing garb or carrying token used by soldier, sailor or airman
description: Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor, or airman in the Military, Naval, or Air Forces, wears any garb or carries any token resembling one used by such forces with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor, or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
example_use_cases: A civilian wears an army uniform to impersonate a soldier and gain respect or privileges.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Unlawful assembly
description: An assembly of five or more persons is designated an "unlawful assembly" if the common object of the persons composing that assembly is to overawe the government by criminal force; to resist the execution of any law or legal process; to commit mischief, criminal trespass or other offence; to use criminal force to obtain possession of property or to deprive any person of any incorporeal right; or to use criminal force to compel any person to do what he is not legally bound to do.
example_use_cases: A mob of people gathering to forcefully prevent a lawful eviction.
punishment: Not a penal section by itself; defines the term for subsequent sections.

section_title: Being member of unlawful assembly
description: Whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly.
example_use_cases: A person joins a protest that has turned violent, knowing that the crowd is now intent on damaging public property.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 143.

section_title: Punishment for unlawful assembly
description: Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Simply being part of a riotous mob of five or more people with a common illegal object.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Joining unlawful assembly armed with deadly weapon
description: Whoever, being armed with any deadly weapon, or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person is part of an unlawful mob while carrying a sword, knife, or iron rod.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Joining or continuing in unlawful assembly, knowing it has been commanded to disperse
description: Whoever joins or continues in an unlawful assembly, knowing that such unlawful assembly has been commanded in the manner prescribed by law to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person remains part of a riotous mob even after a police officer has read out a legal order for the crowd to disperse.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Rioting
description: Whenever force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly, or by any member thereof, in prosecution of the common object of such assembly, every member of such assembly is guilty of the offence of rioting.
example_use_cases: A mob with the common object of damaging a shop proceeds to break its windows and loot its goods. Every member is guilty of rioting.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 147.

section_title: Punishment for rioting
description: Whoever is guilty of rioting, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Participating in a violent mob action.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Rioting, armed with deadly weapon
description: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with a deadly weapon or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person participates in a riot while carrying a firearm, axe, or sharp weapon.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object
description: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed in prosecution of that object, every person who, at the time of the committing of that offence, is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.
example_use_cases: A mob's common object is to beat a person. One member kills that person. Every member of the mob can be charged with murder, as it was a likely consequence of their common object.
punishment: Liable for the same punishment as for the offence committed.

section_title: Hiring, or conniving at hiring, of persons to join unlawful assembly
description: Whoever hires or engages, or employs, or promotes, or connives at the hiring, engagement or employment of any person to join or become a member of any unlawful assembly, shall be punishable as a member of such unlawful assembly, and for any offence which may be committed by any such person.
example_use_cases: A community leader pays people to form a mob to attack a rival community's property. The leader is liable for the rioting and any damage caused.
punishment: Punishment as if they were a member of the unlawful assembly for any offence committed.

section_title: Knowingly joining or continuing in assembly of five or more persons after it has been commanded to disperse
description: Whoever knowingly joins or continues in any assembly of five or more persons likely to cause a disturbance of the public peace, after such assembly has been lawfully commanded to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person continues to be part of an unarmed but disruptive protest after a valid police order to disperse.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Assaulting or obstructing public servant when suppressing riot, etc.
description: Whoever assaults or threatens to assault, or obstructs or attempts to obstruct, any public servant in the discharge of his duty as a public servant, in endeavouring to disperse an unlawful assembly, or to suppress a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Throwing stones at police officers who are trying to control a riot.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot
description: Whoever malignantly, or wantonly, by doing anything which is illegal, gives provocation to any person intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause the offence of rioting to be committed, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Making a highly inflammatory speech in a volatile area with the intention of sparking a communal riot.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony
description: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representations, or otherwise, promotes or attempts to promote, on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, caste or community or any other ground, disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred or ill-will between different groups, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Publishing content online that vilifies a particular religious community and incites hatred against them.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If committed in a place of worship, etc., imprisonment up to five years and fine.

section_title: Imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration
description: Whoever makes or publishes any imputation that any class of persons cannot, by reason of their being members of any religious, racial, language or regional group or caste or community, bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution or uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Claiming that a particular linguistic group is inherently disloyal to the nation.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Owner or occupier of land on which an unlawful assembly is held
description: Whenever any unlawful assembly or riot takes place, the owner or occupier of the land upon which such unlawful assembly is held, or such riot is committed, who does not use all lawful means to prevent it and to disperse the assembly, shall be punished with fine up to one thousand rupees.
example_use_cases: The owner of a field sees a large armed mob gathering on his property and does nothing to stop them or inform the police.
punishment: Fine up to one thousand rupees.

section_title: Liability of person for whose benefit riot is committed
description: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit or on behalf of any person who is the owner or occupier of any land, such person shall be punishable with fine if he does not use all lawful means to prevent such riot.
example_use_cases: A factory owner benefits when a mob attacks a workers' union office. He can be fined if he knew about it and did nothing to prevent it.
punishment: Fine.

section_title: Liability of agent of owner or occupier for whose benefit riot is committed
description: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit of any person who is the owner or occupier of any land, the agent of such person shall be punishable with fine if he did not use all lawful means to prevent such riot.
example_use_cases: The manager of an estate who fails to prevent a riot that benefits the estate owner.
punishment: Fine.

section_title: Harbouring persons hired for an unlawful assembly
description: Whoever harbours, receives or assembles any persons, knowing that such persons have been hired, engaged or employed to join an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Providing food and shelter to people who have been paid to be part of a violent protest.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Being hired to take part in an unlawful assembly or riot
description: Whoever is engaged or hired to offer himself to be a member of an unlawful assembly or to join in a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person accepts money to participate in a mob that will block a highway and cause violence.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Affray
description: When two or more persons, by fighting in a public place, disturb the public peace, they are said to "commit an affray".
example_use_cases: Two people get into a fistfight on a busy street, causing a scene and disturbing the peace.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 160.

section_title: Punishment for committing affray
description: Whoever commits an affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine up to one hundred rupees, or with both.
example_use_cases: The punishment for the two people fighting in the public street.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to one hundred rupees, or both.
