section_title: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person
description: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law as to the way in which he is to conduct himself as such public servant, intending to cause injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A police officer knowingly violates arrest procedures to harass or frame an innocent person.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury
description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being charged with the preparation or translation of any document, frames that document in a manner he knows to be incorrect, with intent to cause injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A revenue officer intentionally prepares a faulty land record to deprive the true owner of their property.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to engage in trade, engages in trade, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A government officer, prohibited from running a business, secretly owns a private company.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property
description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to purchase or bid for certain property, purchases or bids for that property, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A court officer involved in an auction purchases property that is being auctioned by his own court.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both; the property may also be confiscated.

section_title: Personating a public servant
description: Whoever pretends to hold any particular office as a public servant, knowing that he does not hold such office, and does any act under colour of such office, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person dresses as a police officer and conducts a fake raid to extort money.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent
description: Whoever, not belonging to a certain class of public servants, wears any garb or carries any token resembling one used by that class of public servants, with the intention that it may be believed that he belongs to that class, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person wears a fake government ID card to gain unauthorized entry into a secure building.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Definition of “candidate” and “electoral right”
description: For the purposes of this Chapter (Chapter IXA), "candidate" means a person who has been nominated as a candidate at an election. "Electoral right" means the right of a person to stand as a candidate, or to vote.
example_use_cases: Defines terms used in the following sections related to elections.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Bribery
description: Whoever gives a gratification to any person with the object of inducing him to exercise his electoral right in a particular way, or to reward him for having done so, commits bribery. Similarly, whoever accepts such gratification also commits bribery.
example_use_cases: Giving money to voters to vote for a specific candidate.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. If committed by a person who was a candidate, imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Undue influence at elections
description: Whoever voluntarily interferes or attempts to interfere with the free exercise of any electoral right, by threatening injury, or by inducing a belief that divine displeasure will follow, commits the offence of undue influence.
example_use_cases: Threatening to evict a tenant if they do not vote for a particular candidate.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Personation at elections
description: Whoever at an election applies for a voting paper or votes in the name of another person, whether living or dead, or in a fictitious name, or who votes more than once, commits personation.
example_use_cases: A person votes using a dead relative's name.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Punishment for bribery
description: Whoever commits the offence of bribery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Punishment for the act of bribery defined in Section 171B.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Punishment for undue influence or personation at an election
description: Whoever commits the offence of undue influence or personation at an election shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Punishment for the acts defined in Sections 171C and 171D.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: False statement in connection with an election
description: Whoever with intent to affect the result of an election makes or publishes any statement purporting to be a statement of fact which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, in relation to the personal character or conduct of any candidate, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Spreading a false rumor that a candidate has a criminal record.
punishment: Fine.

section_title: Illegal payments in connection with elections
description: Whoever without the general or special authority in writing of a candidate incurs or authorizes expenses on account of the holding of any public meeting, or upon any advertisement, circular or publication, for the purpose of promoting the election of such candidate, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A supporter prints and distributes campaign posters for a candidate without the candidate's authorization.
punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.

section_title: Failure to keep election accounts
description: Whoever, being required by any law to keep accounts of expenses incurred in connection with an election, fails to keep such accounts, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A candidate does not maintain a record of their election campaign spending as required by law.
punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.

section_title: Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceeding
description: Whoever absconds in order to avoid being served with a summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A witness in a case deliberately hides to avoid receiving a summons to appear in court.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Preventing service of summons or other proceeding, or preventing publication thereof
description: Whoever in any manner prevents the serving on himself or on any other person of any summons, notice or order, or prevents the lawful affixing of any such document, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person refuses to open the door to a process server who is trying to serve a court notice.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Not obeying a legal order to attend at a certain place in person or by agent
description: Whoever, being legally bound to appear in person at a certain place, intentionally omits to appear, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person who is summoned to court as a witness deliberately does not show up.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Non-appearance in response to a proclamation under section 82 of CrPC
description: Whoever fails to appear at the specified place and time as required by a proclamation published under subsection (1) of section 82 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A declared absconder continues to evade arrest after a court has issued a proclamation.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If the proclamation was for a bailable offence, imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees.

section_title: Intentionally omitting to produce a document to a public servant by a person legally bound to produce it
description: Whoever, being legally bound to produce or deliver up any document to any public servant, intentionally omits to do so, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person is ordered by a court to produce a land deed as evidence but intentionally withholds it.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Intentionally omitting to give notice or information to a public servant by a person legally bound to give it
description: Whoever, being legally bound to give any notice or information to a public servant, intentionally omits to do so, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person fails to report a fatal accident to the police as required by law.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Knowingly furnishing false information to a public servant
description: Whoever, being legally bound to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, furnishes information which he knows to be false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Giving a false name and address to a police officer during an investigation.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Refusing oath when duly required to take oath by a public servant
description: Whoever refuses to bind himself by an oath to state the truth, when required to do so by a public servant legally competent to require such oath, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A witness in a court case refuses to swear an oath or make a solemn affirmation before testifying.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Being legally bound to state truth, but refusing to answer questions
description: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth on any subject to any public servant, refuses to answer any question demanded of him by such public servant, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A witness in a police investigation refuses to answer questions about what they saw.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Refusing to sign a statement made to a public servant
description: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him when required to do so by a public servant legally competent to require that he sign it, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person gives a written statement to the police but then refuses to sign it.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Knowingly stating to a public servant on oath anything which is false
description: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath to state the truth on any subject, states anything which is false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A witness gives false testimony under oath in a court proceeding (perjury).
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: False information, with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to the injury of another person
description: Whoever gives false information to a public servant, intending to cause such public servant to use his lawful power to injure or annoy another person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Filing a false police complaint against an enemy to get them arrested.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Resistance to the taking of property by the lawful authority of a public servant
description: Whoever offers resistance to the lawful taking of any property by a public servant, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Physically preventing a bailiff from seizing property as per a court's attachment order.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Obstructing sale of property offered for sale by authority of a public servant
description: Whoever intentionally obstructs any sale of property made by a public servant in the execution of his duty, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Creating a disturbance at a public auction conducted by a government official to prevent bidding.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Illegally purchasing or bidding for property offered for sale by authority of a public servant
description: Whoever, at a sale of property held by a public servant, purchases or bids for property that he is not legally entitled to purchase or bid for, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A government employee illegally bids for property being auctioned by their own department.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions
description: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any public servant in the discharge of his public functions, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Blocking a police vehicle from reaching the scene of a crime.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Omission to assist public servant when bound by law to give assistance
description: Whoever, being bound by law to render assistance to any public servant in the execution of his public duty, intentionally omits to give such assistance, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person refuses to help a police officer catch a criminal when the officer lawfully demands their help.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant
description: Whoever knowingly disobeys any order duly promulgated by a public servant, if such disobedience causes obstruction, annoyance or injury to any person lawfully employed, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Violating a curfew order imposed by a District Magistrate.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both. If such disobedience causes danger to human life, etc., imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Threat of injury to public servant
description: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to a public servant to induce him to do any act or to forbear from doing any act connected with his office, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Threatening a tax officer to avoid a high tax assessment.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Threat of injury to induce person to refrain from applying for protection to public servant
description: Whoever holds out a threat of injury to any person to induce him to refrain from making a legal application to a public servant for protection from injury, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Threatening a victim to prevent them from going to the police to file a complaint.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Giving false evidence
description: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
example_use_cases: A witness in court lies under oath about what they saw at a crime scene.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 193.

section_title: Fabricating false evidence
description: Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry or alters any document with the intention that it may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, and thereby cause a person to form an erroneous opinion on a material point, is said to fabricate false evidence.
example_use_cases: Planting fake documents to mislead a court investigation.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 193.

section_title: Punishment for false evidence
description: Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Perjury in a murder trial.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If not in a judicial proceeding, imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of capital offence
description: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence, intending thereby to cause any person to be convicted of an offence which is capital by law, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Framing someone for murder by giving false testimony.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of offence punishable with imprisonment for life
description: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence intending to cause any person to be convicted of an offence which is punishable with imprisonment for life or imprisonment for seven years or more, shall be punished as if he had committed the offence.
example_use_cases: Falsely testifying to get someone convicted for a crime that carries a life sentence.
punishment: Punishment as for the offence they were trying to procure conviction for.

section_title: Threatening any person to give false evidence
description: Whoever threatens another with any injury to his person, property or reputation, to make that person give false evidence or fabricate false evidence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: Threatening a witness to force them to lie in court.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Using evidence known to be false
description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any evidence which he knows to be false or fabricated, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave or fabricated false evidence.
example_use_cases: A lawyer knowingly presenting forged documents in court.
punishment: Punishment as for giving or fabricating false evidence (Section 193).

section_title: Issuing or signing false certificate
description: Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, relating to any fact of which he is legally bound to report the truth, and which he knows to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
example_use_cases: A doctor issuing a false medical certificate of fitness.
punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).

section_title: Using as true a certificate known to be false
description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such certificate as a true certificate, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
example_use_cases: Using a forged educational certificate to get a government job.
punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).

section_title: False statement made in declaration which is by law receivable as evidence
description: Whoever makes any false statement in any declaration which is by law receivable as evidence, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
example_use_cases: Making a false statement in an affidavit submitted to court.
punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).

section_title: Using as true such declaration knowing it to be false
description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such declaration as true, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
example_use_cases: Using a forged affidavit as evidence in a legal proceeding.
punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).

section_title: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender
description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, causes evidence to disappear or gives false information about the offence to screen the offender from legal punishment, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Helping a murderer hide the murder weapon.
punishment: If offence is capital: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If punishable with life imprisonment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. For any other offence: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Intentional omission to give information of offence by person bound to inform
description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, intentionally omits to give any information respecting that offence which he is legally bound to give, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A village headman fails to report a murder he knows about.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Giving false information respecting an offence committed
description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, gives any information respecting that offence which he knows or believes to be false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Providing a false alibi to the police for a suspect.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence
description: Whoever secretes or destroys any document which he may be lawfully compelled to produce as evidence, with intent to prevent its production, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Destroying a contract document that has been subpoenaed for a court case.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: False personation for purpose of act or proceeding in suit or prosecution
description: Whoever falsely personates another, and in such assumed character makes any admission or statement, or confesses judgment, or causes any process to be issued, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Posing as someone else in court to confess to a crime they didn't commit.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution
description: Whoever fraudulently removes, conceals, transfers or delivers to any person any property to prevent its seizure as a forfeiture or in execution of a decree, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Hiding assets to prevent them from being seized by court officials.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Fraudulent claim to property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution
description: Whoever fraudulently accepts, receives or claims any property to prevent its seizure as a forfeiture or in execution of a decree, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Falsely claiming ownership of property that is about to be seized by authorities.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Fraudulently suffering decree for sum not due
description: Whoever fraudulently causes or suffers a decree to be passed against him for a sum not due, to damage or annoy any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Allowing a false court judgment against oneself to harm another's interests.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Dishonestly making false claim in Court
description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly makes a false claim in any Court of Justice, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Filing a false lawsuit claiming ownership of property that belongs to someone else.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.

section_title: Fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due
description: Whoever fraudulently obtains a decree against any person for a sum not due, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Using forged documents to obtain a court judgment in one's favor.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.

section_title: False charge of offence made with intent to injure
description: Whoever makes a false charge of any offence to a public servant, with intent to injure any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Filing a false police report accusing an innocent person of theft.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both. If offence is punishable with imprisonment for seven years or more: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Harbouring offender
description: Whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to be an offender, to screen him from legal punishment, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Hiding a fugitive from justice in one's home.
punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to five years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to three years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Taking gift, etc., to screen an offender from punishment
description: Whoever takes a gift or gratification to screen an offender from punishment, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Accepting a bribe to not report a crime to the police.
punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Offering gift or restoration of property in consideration of screening offender
description: Whoever gives any gratification to screen an offender, or restores property to induce screening, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Paying money to a witness to not testify in court.
punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Taking gift to help to recover stolen property, etc.
description: Whoever takes a gift to help recover movable property of which a person has been deprived by an offence, without using lawful means, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person takes money to help recover stolen goods but has no intention of using legal channels.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Harbouring offender who has escaped from custody or whose apprehension has been ordered
description: Whoever harbours or conceals any person who has escaped from custody or for whose apprehension a warrant has been issued, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Sheltering a prisoner who has broken out of jail.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Penalty for harbouring dacoits
description: Whoever harbours members of a gang of dacoits, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Providing shelter and supplies to a known gang of dacoits.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

description: [Repealed]
example_use_cases: [Repealed]
punishment: [Repealed]

section_title: Public servant disobeying direction of law with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture
description: Whoever, being a public servant, disobeys any direction of law with intent to save any person from legal punishment or any property from forfeiture, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A police officer deliberately fails to arrest a known criminal.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public servant framing incorrect record or writing with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture
description: Whoever, being a public servant, frames an incorrect record or writing with intent to save any person from legal punishment or any property from forfeiture, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A police officer prepares a false report to help a guilty person avoid conviction.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public servant in judicial proceeding corruptly making report, etc., contrary to law
description: Whoever, being a public servant, corruptly makes any report or gives any decision which he knows to be contrary to law, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A judge knowingly gives a wrong judgment in exchange for a bribe.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Commitment for trial or confinement by person having authority who knows that he is acting contrary to law
description: Whoever, being in authority, corruptly or maliciously commits any person for trial or confinement knowing that such action is contrary to law, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A magistrate knowingly orders the detention of a person without legal grounds.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend
description: Whoever, being a public servant legally bound to apprehend or keep in confinement any person, intentionally omits to apprehend him or allows him to escape, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A prison guard deliberately lets a prisoner escape.
punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to three years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to two years and fine.

section_title: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend person under sentence or lawfully committed
description: Whoever, being a public servant, intentionally allows a person under sentence or lawfully committed to custody to escape, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A police officer transporting a convict deliberately lets them go.
punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-half the maximum term for that offence.

section_title: Escape from confinement or custody negligently suffered by public servant
description: Whoever, being a public servant, negligently suffers any person in confinement to escape, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A jail guard falls asleep on duty, allowing a prisoner to escape.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Resistance or obstruction by a person to his lawful apprehension
description: Whoever offers resistance or illegal obstruction to the lawful apprehension of himself or any other person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A suspect physically fights with police officers trying to arrest him.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of another person
description: Whoever offers resistance or illegal obstruction to the lawful apprehension of any other person, or rescues or attempts to rescue any other person from lawful custody, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A mob attacks a police vehicle to free a arrested person.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both. If offence is punishable with death or life imprisonment: imprisonment up to eight years and fine.

section_title: Omission to apprehend, or sufferance of escape, on part of public servant, in cases not otherwise provided for
description: Whoever, being a public servant, illegally omits to apprehend or suffers to escape any person, in cases not otherwise provided for, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A public servant's negligent conduct leads to the escape of a person in a situation not covered by other sections.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension, or escape or rescue in cases not otherwise provided for
description: Whoever resists lawful apprehension, or escapes from custody, in cases not otherwise provided for, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Resisting arrest in a situation not covered by more specific sections.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: [Repealed]
description: [Repealed]
example_use_cases: [Repealed]
punishment: [Repealed]

section_title: Violation of condition of remission of punishment
description: Whoever, having accepted any conditional remission of punishment, violates any condition, shall be punished with the punishment of the original offence.
example_use_cases: A prisoner released early on parole breaks the terms of their parole.
punishment: Punishment for the original offence.

section_title: Intentional insult or interruption to public servant sitting in judicial proceeding
description: Whoever intentionally offers any insult or causes any interruption to any public servant while such public servant is sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Shouting insults at a judge during a court hearing.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Disclosure of identity of the victim of certain offences etc.
description: Whoever prints or publishes the name or any matter which may make known the identity of any person against whom certain sexual offences have been committed, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A newspaper reveals the name of a rape victim.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.

section_title: Personation of a juror or assessor
description: Whoever, by personation or otherwise, intentionally causes himself to be served with a summons as a juror or assessor, or serves on such jury or as such assessor, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Posing as someone else to serve on a jury.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Failure by person released on bail or bond to appear in Court
description: Whoever, having been charged with an offence and released on bail or bond, fails without sufficient cause to appear in court, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person jumps bail and does not show up for their court date.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. If the offence is non-bailable, punishment for the original offence may also be applied.

section_title: 'Coin' defined
description: Coin is defined as metal used for the time being as money, and stamped and issued by the authority of some State or Sovereign Power in order to be so used.
example_use_cases: Indian rupee coins, US dollar coins, or British pound coins.
punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.

section_title: Counterfeiting coin
description: Whoever counterfeits or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Manufacturing fake Indian rupee coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Counterfeiting Indian coin
description: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, Indian coin, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
example_use_cases: Manufacturing fake Indian currency coins with intent to circulate them.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting coin
description: Whoever makes, mends, buys, sells, or disposes of any die or instrument for the purpose of being used in counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling equipment designed to mint counterfeit coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Indian coin
description: Whoever makes, mends, buys, sells, or disposes of any die or instrument for the purpose of being used in counterfeiting Indian coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Creating a mold specifically designed to counterfeit Indian rupee coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting coin
description: Whoever is in possession of any instrument or material for the purpose of using it in counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Being found with blank metal discs and dyes intended for making fake coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If for Indian coin: imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Abetting in India the counterfeiting out of India of coin
description: Whoever, being within India, abets the counterfeiting of coin outside India, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person in India provides designs to someone abroad to counterfeit foreign currency.
punishment: Punishment as for counterfeiting such coin.

section_title: Import or export of counterfeit coin
description: Whoever imports into India, or exports therefrom, any counterfeit coin, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Smuggling fake US dollar coins into India.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Import or export of counterfeits of the Indian coin
description: Whoever imports into India, or exports therefrom, any counterfeit Indian coin, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Smuggling fake Indian rupee coins into or out of the country.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit
description: Whoever, having any counterfeit coin which he knows to be counterfeit, delivers it to another person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Paying for goods with counterfeit coins knowing they are fake.
punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.

section_title: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit
description: Whoever, having any counterfeit Indian coin which he knows to be counterfeit, delivers it to another person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Using fake Indian rupee coins to make a purchase.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Delivery of coin as genuine, which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be counterfeit
description: Whoever delivers to another any counterfeit coin as genuine, which he did not know to be counterfeit when he took it into his possession, but subsequently discovered to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A shopkeeper receives a counterfeit coin as change and, upon realizing it is fake, uses it to pay another customer.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine up to ten times the value of the coin, or both.

section_title: Possession of counterfeit coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof
description: Whoever, with knowledge that a coin is counterfeit, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Holding onto counterfeit coins with the intent to use them later.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof
description: Whoever, with knowledge that an Indian coin is counterfeit, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Being in possession of fake Indian rupee coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Person employed in mint causing coin to be of different weight or composition from that fixed by law
description: Whoever, being employed in a mint, causes a coin to be of a different weight or composition than that established by law, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A mint worker deliberately produces coins with less metal content than required.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Unlawfully taking from mint any coining instrument
description: Whoever, without lawful authority, takes from a mint any tool or instrument used for coining, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Stealing a dye or press from the government mint.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of coin
description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly diminishes the weight or alters the composition of any coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Shaving off bits of metal from coins to sell the metal.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of Indian coin
description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly diminishes the weight or alters the composition of any Indian coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Altering the composition of an Indian rupee coin.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Altering appearance of coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description
description: Whoever alters the appearance of any coin with the intent that it shall pass as a coin of a different description, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Plating a low-value coin with gold to make it resemble a high-value coin.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Altering appearance of Indian coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description
description: Whoever alters the appearance of any Indian coin with the intent that it shall pass as a coin of a different description, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Altering a ₹5 coin to make it look like a ₹10 coin.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered
description: Whoever, having a coin whose weight or composition has been altered, delivers it to another person, knowing it to be altered, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Using a coin that has been shaved down to make a purchase.
punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.

section_title: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered
description: Whoever, having an Indian coin whose weight or composition has been altered, delivers it to another person, knowing it to be altered, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Paying with an altered Indian rupee coin.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Possession of coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof
description: Whoever, with knowledge that a coin has been altered, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Holding onto coins that have been fraudulently diminished in weight.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.

section_title: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof
description: Whoever, with knowledge that an Indian coin has been altered, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Being in possession of altered Indian rupee coins.
punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.

section_title: Delivery of coin as genuine which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be altered
description: Whoever delivers to another an altered coin as genuine, which he did not know to be altered when he took it into his possession, but subsequently discovered to be altered, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person receives an altered coin as change and, after realizing it, uses it to pay someone else.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine up to ten times the value of the coin, or both.

section_title: Counterfeiting Government stamp
description: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Manufacturing fake court fee stamps or revenue stamps.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Having possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting Government stamp
description: Whoever has in his possession any instrument or material for the purpose of counterfeiting any Government stamp, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Possessing paper, ink, or plates specifically designed to create fake revenue stamps.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Government stamp
description: Whoever makes, performs any part of the process of making, buys, sells, or disposes of any instrument for the purpose of counterfeiting any Government stamp, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling a printing press designed to create counterfeit government stamps.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Sale of counterfeit Government stamp
description: Whoever sells, or offers for sale, any counterfeit Government stamp, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling fake court fee stamps.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Having possession of counterfeit Government stamp
description: Whoever has in his possession any counterfeit Government stamp, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Holding a quantity of counterfeit revenue stamps.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Using as genuine a Government stamp known to be counterfeit
description: Whoever uses as genuine any Government stamp known to be counterfeit, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Affixing a fake court fee stamp to a legal document.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Effacing writing from substance bearing Government stamp, or removing from document a stamp used for it, with intent to cause loss to Government
description: Whoever, with intent to cause loss to Government, effaces any writing from a substance bearing a Government stamp, or removes from a document a stamp that has been used for it, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Removing a used revenue stamp from one document to reuse it on another.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Using Government stamp known to have been before used
description: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to Government, uses any Government stamp which has been before used, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Reusing a postage stamp or revenue stamp that has already been canceled.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Erasure of mark denoting that stamp has been used
description: Whoever erases or removes any mark indicating that a stamp has been used, with intent to use it again, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Removing the cancellation mark from a used postage stamp.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Prohibition of fictitious stamps
description: (1) Whoever makes, sells, or uses any fictitious stamp, or knowingly has in his possession any fictitious stamp, shall be punished. (2) A fictitious stamp means any stamp that resembles a Government stamp but is not issued by the Government.
example_use_cases: Producing or selling fake postage stamps that look like real ones.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Fraudulent use of false instrument for weighing
description: Whoever fraudulently uses any instrument for weighing which he knows to be false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A shopkeeper uses a rigged weighing scale to cheat customers.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Fraudulent use of false weight or measure
description: Whoever fraudulently uses any false weight or false measure of length or capacity, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Using a shortened measuring tape or underweight weights in trade.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Being in possession of false weight or measure
description: Whoever is in possession of any false weight or measure, knowing it to be false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A merchant keeps altered weights in his shop intending to use them.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Making or selling false weight or measure
description: Whoever makes, sells, or disposes of any weight or measure which he knows to be false, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Manufacturing and selling rigged weighing scales.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Public nuisance
description: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public or to the people in general who dwell or occupy property in the vicinity.
example_use_cases: Blocking a public road, causing loud noise at night, or polluting a public water source.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 290.

section_title: Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
description: Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A person with a contagious disease knowingly travels in a crowded bus.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
description: Whoever malignantly does any act which is likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Intentionally spreading a dangerous disease by contaminating food or water.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Disobedience to quarantine rule
description: Whoever knowingly disobeys any rule made and promulgated by the Government for putting any vessel into a state of quarantine, or for regulating the intercourse of such vessel with the shore, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A ship captain ignores quarantine protocols during an outbreak.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale
description: Whoever adulterates any article of food or drink, so as to make such article noxious as food or drink, intending to sell it, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Mixing water with milk or adding harmful chemicals to food products for sale.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Sale of noxious food or drink
description: Whoever sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any article of food or drink which he knows to be noxious, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling spoiled meat or contaminated beverages.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Adulteration of drugs
description: Whoever adulterates any drug or medical preparation so as to lessen its efficacy or to make it noxious, intending to sell it, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Diluting medicine with inactive ingredients to increase quantity.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Sale of adulterated drugs
description: Whoever sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any drug or medical preparation which he knows to be adulterated, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling diluted or fake medicines.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Sale of drug as a different drug or preparation
description: Whoever knowingly sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any drug or medical preparation as a different drug or preparation, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling a cheap medicine as an expensive branded drug.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Fouling water of public spring or reservoir
description: Whoever voluntarily corrupts or fouls the water of any public spring or reservoir, so as to render it less fit for the purpose for which it is ordinarily used, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Dumping industrial waste into a public water source.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

section_title: Making atmosphere noxious to health
description: Whoever voluntarily vitiates the atmosphere in any place so as to make it noxious to the health of persons in general dwelling or carrying on business in the neighbourhood, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Releasing toxic fumes from a factory in a residential area.
punishment: Imprisonment up to five hundred rupees.

section_title: Rash driving or riding on a public way
description: Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides, on any public way in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Driving a car at high speed in a crowded market area.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Rash navigation of vessel
description: Whoever navigates any vessel in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Operating a boat in a reckless manner in a crowded waterway.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Exhibition of false light, mark or buoy
description: Whoever exhibits any false light, mark or buoy, intending that such exhibition may mislead any navigator, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Setting up a fake lighthouse signal that causes a ship to run aground.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Conveying person by water for hire in unsafe or overloaded vessel
description: Whoever knowingly or negligently conveys, or causes to be conveyed, any person by water in any vessel, when that vessel is in such a state or so loaded as to endanger the life of that person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A ferry operator overloads his boat with passengers.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation
description: Whoever, by doing any act, or by omitting to take order with any property in his possession or under his charge, causes danger, obstruction or injury to any person in any public way or line of navigation, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Leaving construction materials blocking a sidewalk or road.
punishment: Fine up to two hundred rupees.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance
description: Whoever does, with any poisonous substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Leaving poisonous pesticides open and accessible to children.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter
description: Whoever does, with fire or any combustible matter, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Carelessly storing gasoline near a source of heat.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to explosive substance
description: Whoever does, with any explosive substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Handling fireworks negligently in a crowded area.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to machinery
description: Whoever does, with any machinery, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Operating industrial equipment without safety guards.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to pulling down or repairing buildings
description: Whoever, in pulling down or repairing any building, knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with that building as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life from the fall of that building or of any part thereof, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Failing to put up safety nets during building demolition.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to animal
description: Whoever knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with any animal in his possession as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life, or any probable danger of grievous hurt from such animal, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Allowing a dangerous dog to roam freely in a public park.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Punishment for public nuisance in cases not otherwise provided for
description: Whoever commits a public nuisance in any case not otherwise punishable by this Code, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Creating excessive smoke or noise that annoys the public.
punishment: Fine up to two hundred rupees.

section_title: Continuance of nuisance after injunction to discontinue
description: Whoever repeats or continues a public nuisance, having been enjoined by any public servant who has lawful authority to issue such injunction not to repeat or continue such nuisance, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Continuing to play loud music after being warned by the police to stop.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Sale, etc., of obscene books, etc.
description: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, publicly exhibits or in any manner puts into circulation, any obscene book, pamphlet, paper, drawing, painting, representation or figure or any other obscene object, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling or distributing pornography.
punishment: First conviction: imprisonment up to two years and fine up to two thousand rupees. Subsequent conviction: imprisonment up to five years and fine up to five thousand rupees.

section_title: Sale, etc., of obscene objects to young person
description: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, exhibits or circulates any obscene object to any person under the age of twenty years, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Selling pornographic material to a minor.
punishment: First conviction: imprisonment up to three years and fine up to two thousand rupees. Subsequent conviction: imprisonment up to seven years and fine up to five thousand rupees.

section_title: Obscene acts and songs
description: Whoever, to the annoyance of others, does any obscene act in any public place, or sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words in or near any public place, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Using lewd language or performing indecent acts in a public place.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Keeping lottery office
description: Whoever keeps any office or place for the purpose of drawing any lottery not being a State lottery or a lottery authorized by the State Government, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Operating an illegal gambling or lottery house.
punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

section_title: Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class
description: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship, or any object held sacred by any class of persons, with the intention of thereby insulting the religion of any class of persons, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Vandalizing a temple, mosque, church, or gurdwara.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs
description: Whoever, with deliberate and malicious intention of outraging the religious feelings of any class of citizens, insults or attempts to insult the religion or the religious beliefs of that class, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Creating and sharing content online that deeply insults a religious community.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Disturbing religious assembly
description: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship, or religious ceremonies, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Disrupting a prayer meeting or a religious procession with loud noise.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Trespassing on burial places, etc.
description: Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, commits any trespass in any place of worship or on any place of sepulchre, or any place set apart for the performance of funeral rites, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Desecrating a grave or a cremation ground.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Uttering words, etc., with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings
description: Whoever, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of any person, utters any word or makes any sound in the hearing of that person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Making derogatory remarks about a person's deity or prophet.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

section_title: Culpable homicide
description: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.
example_use_cases: A person attacks another with a weapon, not necessarily intending to kill but knowing the act is likely to cause death.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 304.

section_title: Murder
description: Except in the cases of exceptions, culpable homicide is murder if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or if it is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or if it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or if the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death.
example_use_cases: Intentionally shooting someone in the head; stabbing someone in the heart.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 302.

section_title: Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than person whose death was intended
description: If a person, by doing anything which he intends or knows to be likely to cause death, commits culpable homicide by causing the death of any person, whose death he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause, the culpable homicide committed by the offender is of the description of which it would have been if he had caused the death of the person whose death he intended or knew himself to be likely to cause.
example_use_cases: A intends to kill B but misses and kills C instead. A is guilty of the murder of C.
punishment: Punishment for the offence as if the intended person had been killed.

section_title: Punishment for murder
description: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Premeditated killing; killing during a robbery.
punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine.

section_title: Punishment for murder by life-convict
description: Whoever, being under sentence of imprisonment for life, commits murder, shall be punished with death.
example_use_cases: A person already serving a life sentence kills another inmate or a prison guard.
punishment: Death.

section_title: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder
description: Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine, if the act is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death; or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both, if the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death.
example_use_cases: A death caused in a sudden fight without premeditation; a death caused by a negligent act that falls short of murder.
punishment: If intentional: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine. If with knowledge but no intention: imprisonment up to ten years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Causing death by negligence
description: Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Death caused by rash driving; medical negligence during surgery.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Dowry death
description: Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry, such death shall be called "dowry death".
example_use_cases: A woman is found dead in her matrimonial home within a few years of marriage, with evidence of ongoing harassment for dowry.
punishment: Imprisonment not less than seven years but which may extend to imprisonment for life.

section_title: Abetment of suicide of child or insane person
description: If any person under eighteen years of age, any insane person, any delirious person, any idiot, or any person in a state of intoxication, commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Encouraging or helping a minor to commit suicide.
punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Abetment of suicide
description: If any person commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: Relentless bullying or harassment that drives a person to take their own life.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Attempt to murder
description: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances, that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Shooting at someone but missing; administering a non-lethal dose of poison.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine. If hurt is caused: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Attempt to commit culpable homicide
description: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: An attack that is likely to cause death but is not done with the specific intention to murder.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If hurt is caused: imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Attempt to commit suicide
description: Whoever attempts to commit suicide and does any act towards the commission of such offence, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
example_use_cases: A person survives a suicide attempt.
punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. (Note: This section is widely read down and not actively enforced in many jurisdictions)

section_title: Thug
description: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied with murder, is a thug.
example_use_cases: Being part of a gang that murders people to rob them.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 311.

section_title: Punishment
description: Whoever is a thug, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
example_use_cases: A member of a gang that operates as thugs.
punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine.

section_title: Causing miscarriage
description: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall be punished. If the woman is quick with child, the punishment is higher.
example_use_cases: A person administers drugs to a pregnant woman to terminate her pregnancy without her consent or medical justification.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If quick with child: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Causing miscarriage without woman's consent
description: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section without the consent of the woman, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Forcibly causing a woman to miscarry against her will.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage
description: Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A botched illegal abortion procedure that results in the death of the woman.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth
description: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of preventing that child from being born alive or causing it to die after its birth, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Injuring a pregnant woman to cause the death of the fetus or newborn child.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide
description: Whoever does any act under such circumstances that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A violent assault on a pregnant woman that kills her viable fetus.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

section_title: Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years, by parent or person having care of it
description: Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, exposes or leaves such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning it, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Leaving a newborn baby in a garbage dump.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body
description: Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child, whether such child dies before or after or during its birth, intentionally conceals or endeavours to conceal the birth of such child, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Burying a stillborn child in a backyard to hide the pregnancy.
punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Hurt
description: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.
example_use_cases: Slapping someone, pushing them, or causing them to become ill.
punishment: Punishment as per subsequent sections.

section_title: Grievous hurt
description: The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous": Emasculation; Permanent privation of the sight of either eye; Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear; Privation of any member or joint; Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint; Permanent disfiguration of the head or face; Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth; Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.
example_use_cases: Blinding someone in one eye; breaking a leg; causing a permanent facial scar.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 325.

section_title: Voluntarily causing hurt
description: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person, or with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause hurt to any person, and thereby causes hurt to any person, is said "voluntarily to cause hurt".
example_use_cases: Intentionally punching someone and causing them pain.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 323.

section_title: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt
description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt which he intends to cause or knows himself to be likely to cause is grievous hurt, is said "voluntarily to cause grievous hurt".
example_use_cases: Intentionally attacking someone with a weapon, knowing it is likely to cause serious injury.
punishment: Punishment as per Section 325.

section_title: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt
description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: A fistfight where one person injures another.
punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

section_title: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means
description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Stabbing someone with a knife; throwing acid; setting someone on fire.
punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.

section_title: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt
description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: An attack that results in a broken bone or the loss of an eye.
punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

section_title: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means
description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: An acid attack that causes permanent disfigurement; a shooting that causes a permanent injury.
punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

section_title: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid
description: Whoever causes permanent or partial damage or deformity to, or burns or maims or disfigures or disables, any part or parts of the body of a person, or causes grievous hurt by throwing acid on or administering acid to that person, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Throwing acid on a person's face, causing severe burns and blindness.
punishment: Imprisonment not less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and fine.

section_title: Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid
description: Whoever throws or attempts to throw acid on any person with the intention of causing permanent or partial damage or deformity or burns or maiming or disfigurement or disability or grievous hurt, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Attempting to throw acid on someone but missing or being prevented.
punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to seven years, and fine.

section_title: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort property, or to constrain to an illegal act
description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt for the purpose of extorting any property or valuable security, or of constraining any person to do anything which is illegal or which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished.
example_use_cases: Torturing someone to force them to sign over property.
punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
